metadata.markdown:
SunTech, a Chinese company, until recently was the world's leading solar cell manufacturer in terms of production capacity. One of their products is the solar module PerformaTM Pluto-Ade. The specs of this module are given in the figure below. The objective of this task is to analyze the external parameters of the module using the data presented.

1) What is the maximum power output of the module?

195 W 200 W 263 W 295 W

2) What is the efficiency of the module?

12.3% 14.4% 15.7% 16.8%

3) The open circuit voltage of single solar cell is 630.5 mV. How many solar cells does the module contain when all the solar cells of the module are connected in 'Series'?

24 36 54 72

4) What will be the efficiency of a single cell?

12.8% 15.7% 16.2% 17.8%

5) What will be the Fill-factor (FF) of a single cell?

0.68 0.76 0.84 1

Consider the following statements concerned with interconnecting solar cells to make a solar module. Which of the statements is FALSE?

( ) The open circuit voltage of a solar module with series connected solar cells is the sum of the open circuit voltages of all the individual solar cells.  

(x) The short circuit current of a solar module with series connected solar cells is the sum of the short circuit currents of all the individual solar cells.  

( ) The use of bypass diodes in a solar module can help in reducing the undesired effects of a dysfunctional solar cell. The bypass diode is connected in parallel to a solar cell but with a polarity opposite to that of the solar cell.

     
[explanation]
In a series connection, the voltages of the individual components add up but the current through the components remains the same.
In a parallel connection, the currents of the individual components add up but the voltage across them remains the same. 
Bypass diodes are connected across (in parallel to) a solar cell or a group of solar cells, but with a polarity opposite to that of the solar cell(s). The sse of a bypass diode helps in bypassing a dysfunctional solar cell(s). 
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
According to the molecular description of the band gap, which of the following statements is TRUE?
     ( ) The anti-bonding level is a lower energy state than the bonding level.
     (x) The anti-bonding level is a higher energy state than the bonding level.
     ( ) The closer the two neighboring atoms making an molecular orbital are together, the smaller the energy splitting between the bonding and anti-bonding levels. 
     ( ) The bonding state of a molecular orbital represents the conduction band. 
     
[explanation]
In a simplified picture, the anti-bonding level corresponds to the conduction band and the bonding level corresponds to the valence band. This means that the energy level of the anti-bonding is higher in reference to the bonding level.
[explanation]

As far as the Shockley-Queisser limit is regarded, which of the following PV technologies has more room for improvement to achieve the maximum theoretical efficiency?
     ( ) c-Si
     ( ) GaAs
     ( ) InP
     (x) a-Si:H
     
[explanation]
Looking at the graph shown in the "Spectral Utilization 2" video, minute 5:37, we can see that the record efficiency of a-Si:H is less than half the maximum theoretical efficiency set by the Shockley-Queisser limit.
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
We have identical crystalline silicon solar cells available, with a short-circuit current of 4A and an open-circuit voltage of 0.6V at STC. If a PV module is formed by 54 crystalline silicon solar cells in series, what is the open-circuit voltage of the module, in volts, at STC? Assume that the interconnection losses are negligible.

= 32.4 +- .61

Which is the short-circuit current of the module in amps at STC?
= 4 +- 0.1

Assume that the module does not have any bypass diodes. If the module is partially shaded and one of the cells is able to produce only 2A, what will be the new short-circuit current under these conditions in amps?
= 2 +-0.1

[explanation]
If all the cells are in series, the voltage will be added to get the open-circuit voltage of the module.

Voc = 0.6V*54 = 32.4V

On the other hand, the short-circuit current of a solar module with all the solar cells in series is the same as the solar cell with the lowest current. At STC, that means that the short-circuit current will be 4A. 

If there is partial shading, the shaded cell will lower the current of the whole module to 2A. That is why bypass diodes are intoduced, to inculde an alternative path for the current of non-shaded cells when some of them are shaded.
[explanation]

metadata.display_name: 2.5 Diffusion Current Density vs. Drift Current Density
EQE of a Tandem Cell II
Design Rules of the c-Si Solar Cell

metadata.markdown:
We have dicussed that a bare crystalline silicon surface contains many defects which act as SRH recombination centers. How can the surface recombination at the air/n-silicon interface be reduced?
Note that you can mark more than one answer. 
     [ ] By decreasing the doping of the n-layer.
     [x] By increasing the doping of the n-layer. 
     [x] By depositing a thin insulating layer on top of the n-layer. 
     [ ] By depositing a thin conductive layer on top of the n-layer. 
     
[explanation]
The lower the minority charge carrier density near the surface, the lower the recombination velocity at the surface. By increasing the doping of the n-layer, we can reduce the minority charge carrier density near the surface. 

Depositing a thin layer on top of the silicon layer reduces the number of defects at the silicon surface, since some of the dangling bonds are passivated. The material must be an insulator in order to force the electrons to remain in the silicon layer. 

[explanation]
metadata.display_name: 4.3 Surface Recombination at the Air/Silicon Interface
Week 7: PV Systems - Components and Concepts

metadata.markdown:
Consider a 250 Wp rated monocrystalline PV module. It results from a manufacturing process that consumes 10kWh/Wp of energy. 

What is the total energy consumed in kWh by the module in its production?
= 2500 +- 0
[explanation]
The total energy consumed in the manufacture of the module is 10kWh/Wp * 250 Wp = 2500 kWh
[explanation]

Assume that the PV module is used in a location where it gives an average annual PV yield of 500kWh over its lifetime of 25 years.
What is the Energy Yield Ratio of the PV module over its lifetime of 25 years?
= 5 +- 0%

[explanation]
Energy Yield Ratio = (Total PV module Yield over the lifetime)/(Energy invested in the PV module) = (500kWh/year * 25 years)/(2500 kWh) = 5.
[explanation]

What is the Energy payback period in years for the PV module?
= 5

[explanation]
Energy Payback period is the time taken by the PV module to yield the same amount of energy as invested in its production. In this case, at an average annual yield of 500kWh, the PV module yields its production energy of 2500kWh in (2500kWh)/(500kWh/year) = 5 years.
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
What is the proper order, from lower purity to higher purity, of the following types of silicon? 

     ( ) Metallurgical silicon / Mono-crystalline silicon / Poly-silicon 
     ( ) Mono-crystalline silicon / Poly-silicon / Metallurgical silicon
     (x) Metallurgical silicon / Poly-silicon / Mono-crystalline silicon 
     ( ) Poly-silicon / Metallurgical silicon / Mono-crystalline silicon 
     

[explanation]
Metallurgical silicon is usually used as a intermediate purification step for the manufacturing of modules. Therefore, is the least pure one. Poly-crystalline, due to the higher rate of groth, includes more defects and impurities than mono-dcrystalline
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Which of the charge-carrier recombination mechanisms below, occurs due to the electron-hole recombination via a defect state in the bandgap?
( ) Radiative recombination
( ) Auger recombination
(x) Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) recombination
( ) All of the above 

[explanation]
Radiative recombination takes place when an electron in the conduction band relaxes to the valence band via the emission of a photon. Auger recombination needs an interaction between at least two electrons in the conduction band, so the first electron recombines with a hole and transfers its energy to the second electron. Instead of an interaction between two electrons, Auger recombination can occur through an interaction between two holes in the valence band. The first hole recombines with an electron and transfers its energy to the second hole. 
[explanation]

The effect of shading on a solar cell is undesirable as it reduces the current output from the shaded cell. What techniques can be used to minimize this loss of energy due to shading ?
a. Modules connected in parallel. This will have a smaller impact which is localized to the shaded module alone and not across the entire string of modules.
b. By the usage of by-pass diodes between cells connected in series.
c. Proper planning of the installation of the solar system such that it does not come in direct view of trees and other building objects over the day.
d. By using a special layer of glass over the solar module to minimize shading
( ) Only 'b' is true
( ) 'a' and 'b' are true
(x) 'a', 'b' and 'c' are true
( ) All the options are true

metadata.display_name: 2.5 Diffusion Current Density VS Drift Current Density

metadata.markdown:
Consider the following statements regarding a purely grid-connected PV system design.
	a) A grid connected system does not necessarily need a battery storage, because the grid can uptake and feed power when needed.
    b) The PV system should be designed such that the PV array continues to feed the grid, even in the event of a grid network failure. 
    c) The grid connected PV system can only be designed around the required load that needs to be powered.
    d) The PV array configuration should ensure that the DC current and voltage limits at the input of the inverter are respected.
    
Which of the above statements is/are NOT true?

     ( ) a) and b) only
     (x) b) and c) only
     ( ) All of a), b), c) and d)
     ( ) c) and d) only
     
[explanation]
The grid connected PV system should be designed such that it disconnects from the grid in the event of a grid network failure to prevent islanding. Usually this task is performed by the grid-connected inverter, an integral part of the grid-connected PV system.
Also, the PV system needs not be designed based on the load demand only. If the system is oversized, the extra energy could be supplied to the grid. On the other hand, an undersized system would depend on the grid for the remainder of the load demand.
[explanation]

( ) Solar desiccant
( ) Heat pump
( ) Solar absorption

[explanation]
PCM corresponds to Phase-Change Materials. They are used as a method to store thermal energy as latent heat which is not a cooling technique.
[explanation]

Which is the most important heat transfer mechanism in the domestic heating systems?
     ( ) Conduction
     (x) Convection
     ( ) Radiation
     ( ) All of them are equally important
     
[explanation]
When transporting heat in the domestic heating systems, the heat is usually transported by hot water through the pipes, which is "forced convection". Once it arrives to the heater, there will be slight heat transfer due to radiation and conduction, but the mechanism that transfers the heat from the heater to the rest of the room is mainly natural convection. Therefore, convection, in both natural and forced form, is the main heat transfer mechanisms for domestic solar water heating systems.
[explanation]

What is the maximum number of electrons that can occupy the 3p energy state in an atom?

( ) 2 electrons.
(x) 6 electrons.
( ) Only 1 electron can occupy this state according to the Pauli exclusion principle.
( ) 8 electrons.

[explanation]
There are three p orbitals in the 3p energy state, and only two electrons can occupy each orbital. Therefore, the maximum number of electrons in all the three orbitals in the 3p energy state is 3*2=6 electrons.
[explanation]

Which of the following statements is NOT true about the output of PV cells?
     ( ) The rest of the conditions remaining the same, output power decreases with increase in temperature.
     (x) The rest of the conditions remaining the same, output current decreases with increase in temperature.
     ( ) The rest of the conditions remaining the same, output voltage decreases with increase in temperature.
     ( ) The rest of the conditions remaining the same, output current increases with increase in temperature.
     

     
[explanation]
While the voltage and power have a negative temperature coefficient, the current has a positive temperature coefficient, i.e, the PV current increases with increase in temperature
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following statements are NOT true:
     (x) The levelized cost of electricity depends on the insolation, the cost of PV systems, the discount rate and the cost of electricity coming from the grid at the particular location
     ( ) Grid parity is achieved when the levelized cost of electricity is equal to the electricity cost at a particular location
     ( ) The levelized cost of electricity can be used to compare the electricity price coming from PV and from solar thermal energy.
     ( ) The achievement of grid parity depends on the insolation, the cost of PV systems, the discount rate and the cost of electricity coming from the grid at the particular location
     
[explanation]
The levelized cost of electricity can be defined as the cost per kWh of electricity produced by a power generation project. It does not depend on the cost of electricity coming from the grid. In turn, it is used to compare the cost of electricity coming from the grid with the cost of the electricity coming from a PV system.
[explanation]

HW 5.4 EQE of a Tandem Cell

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following mechanisms can be used in order to split a high energy photon in two (or more) lower energy photons?
     ( ) Multijunction 
     ( ) Up conversion
     (x) Down conversion
     ( ) Intermediate band
     

[explanation]
The multijunction approach uses two materials with different bandgaps in order to improve the spectral utilization and reduce the thermal losses. 
The up conversion mechanism uses two low energy photons that are not absorbed by the PV active material and converts them into one photon with an energy above the bandgap of the PV active material. 
Finally, the intermediate band approach is based on the incorporation of an electronic band within the bandgap in order to enable photons below the bandgap to excite electrons into the conduction band. 
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding ‘Diffusion’ of charge carriers in semiconductors?
(x) Diffusion occurs only in the presence of an electric field 
( ) During diffusion, net flow of carriers takes place from high concentration to low concentration regions
( ) Over time, carriers will diffuse randomly throughout the cell, until concentrations of different regions are uniform
( ) Diffusion occurs faster at higher temperatures

[explanation]
Diffusion occurs as long as there is a concentration gradient, thus an electric field is not needed. The electric field, on the other hand, will be responsible of drifting the charge carriers, yielding a drift current density. 
[explanation]

Consider the electronic band diagram of a p-n junction under equilibrium. Which of the following statements forces the conduction and valence band to bend in the space charge region?
(x) The Fermi level must be constant across the entire junction. 
( ) The energy difference between the conduction band, valence band and the Fermi level must stay constant in equilibrium.
( ) The space charge region is totally depleted of mobile charge carriers.

[explanation] 
2.- The energy difference between the conduction and valence band energies and the Fermi energy is constant in the quasi-neutral regions (far away from the space charge region), but varies within the space charge region.
3.- There are actually some charge carriers within the space charge region. However, their charge is negligible compared with the total space charge in this region.
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Consider a p-n junction under forward-bias voltage. Which of the following statements are TRUE? 
You can select more than one option!!

[x] The applied voltage is positive with respect to the potential of the p-type region.
[x] Nearly all the applied field is dropped across the depletion region.
[ ] The concentrations of electrons and holes can be described by the same Fermi energy.
[ ] The potential barrier across the junction is decreased and the space charge region becomes wider. 
[ ] A net current can be observed because the current caused by the drift of minority carriers is higher than that caused by the diffusion of minority carriers.


[explanation] 
3.- A forward-biased p-n junction is not in equilibrium any more, and the concentrations of mobile carriers are described by the quasi-Fermi energy for electrons and holes, whose difference is proportional to the applied voltage.
4.- The space charge region becomes narrower due to a reduced electric field. 
5.- The drift current is lower than the diffusion current due to a lower electric field and a higher concentration gradient. 
[explanation]

Listed below are some of the important aspects involved in a PV system.

a)Providing optimum charge to the batteries.
b)Prevent overcharging of batteries.
c)Providing deep discharge protection to the batteries.
d)Supply information on the state of charge (SoC) of the batteries.
e)Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) of the PV module/array.

A common device found in the present day standalone PV system is the charge controller. Which of the above can be performed by a modern day charge controller?

     ( ) b) and c) only.
     ( ) a), b) and c) only.
     ( ) b), c) and d) only.
     ( ) b), c) and e) only.
     (x) All of the above
     
[explanation]
The modern day charge controller is designed to perform all of the 5 functions mentioned in above. While a), b) and c) are considered fundamental tasks of a charge controller, the modern charge controller can also be designed in a way so as to support additional features like displaying SoC of the battery system, and having an inbuilt MPPT mechanism.
[explanation]

metadata.display_name: Design Rules of the c-Si Solar Cell

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following variables does NOT affect the economic payback period of a PV system?
( ) Insolation received by the PV system
( ) Subsidies and feed-in tariffs
( ) Cost of electricity
(x) Overall lifetime of the PV system 

[explanation]
The economic payback period is defined as the time required to recover the cost of an investment. Subsidies and feed-in tariffs affect the initial investment and return rate of the investment. The insolation recieved by the system will affect the PV yield, which in will determine also the return rate. Finally, the cost of electricity will also affect the return rate.
The overall lifetime of the PV system does not affect the payback period, even though it is often used to compare with the payback period to determine if the system is economically feasible. 
[explanation]

Why should the front n-layer of a c-Si solar cell be thinner than the p-layer?

     ( ) The solar cell would actually have the same performance if the n-layer were thicker than the p-layer, as long as a p-n junction is created between these two.
     ( ) Because the diffusion length of the photo-generated holes is larger in the n-layer than in the p-layer. 
     ( ) Because n-doping is required to absorb the incoming light.  
     (x) Because most of the photons are absorbed close to the front surface of the solar cell and the thickness should be smaller than the hole diffusion length in the emitter.
    
     
[explanation]
As we can see in the graph of the generation rate versus the cell depth, the vast majority of the photons are absorbed within the first 10 microns of the solar cell. If the front n-layer were as thick as the p-layer, all these carriers would be generated too far from the p-n junction, and their collection would be inefficient. Chosing an n-layer thickness of 1 micron ensures that most of the charge carriers are generated within the diffusion length of the p-n junction. 
[explanation]

metadata.display_name: 1.3 Power Spectral Density and Photon Flux

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following statements is TRUE about monocrystalline and multicrystalline silicon?

     (x) SRH recombinations are more important in multicrystalline than in monocrystalline silicon. 
     ( ) Higher open-circuit voltages are obtained with multicrystalline than with monocrystalline silicon. 
     ( ) The open-circuit voltage increases as the grain size of the multicrystalline silicon absorber layer decreases. 
     ( ) The lifetime of minority charge carriers is higher in multicrystalline than in monocrystalline silicon. 
     
[explanation]
The grain boundaries in multicrystalline silicon increase the number of defects in the bulk of the material. This makes SRH recombinations more likely to happen, decreasing the lifetime of the charge carriers and hence the open-circuit voltage. The larger the grain size, the larger the carrier lifetime and the larger the open-circuit voltage will be. 
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
What does it mean that the water heating system consists in an open loop?

     ( ) The solar water heating system is used for heating instead of power production
     (x) The fluid that is heated in the collector is directly used to cover the heating demand
     ( ) The flow of the collector liquid is caused by natural convection
     ( ) The fluid of the collector liquid is caused by forced convection
     
[explanation]
An open loop system means that the fluid that is heated in the collector is directly used for heating purposes, without transferring the heat to another fluid via a heat exchanger. That intermediary step is removed.
[explanation]

Which of the following statements is NOT true about solar inverters?
     ( ) A standalone inverter is supposed to work as an AC voltage source for a specified range of AC loads.
     ( ) An ideal grid-tied inverter has its operational voltage and frequency synchronized with those of the grid.
     ( ) A bimodal inverter can power backup loads even if the grid-connection is disrupted.
     (x) An ideal grid-tied inverter works as a perfect voltage source, and changes the grid voltage and frequency to match its own.

     
[explanation]
The ideal grid tied inverter sychronizes its own voltage and frequency based on that of the grid. 
[explanation]

metadata.markdown: Which are the main advantages of a solar tower power plant? Mark all the options you identify as correct. [x] Easy storage of energy [x] High temperature fluid, which results in higher efficiencies [ ] Compact and modular [ ] Low investment costs [explanation] Fluids at higher temperatures are considered to contain a higher quality heat, since their exergy is higher. Exergy is defined as the maximum useful work a system can produce. For more information about exergy, you can visit this page. Therefore, hot fluids in general can give higher efficiencies in generators and heat engines. In addition, since the heat collection is centralized in one single point high fluid temperatures, the storage is easier and more efficient, since one can use packed beds and PCMs, which have higher storage capacity. However, solar tower power plants are big installations with high investment costs and cannot easily be expanded. [explanation]

Band Gap I: Electrons in Atoms

metadata.markdown:
In case of p-doping of Si, the energy of the acceptor state:
( ) is located in the Si bandgap, relatively close to the conduction band.
( ) is located out of the Si bandgap, relatively close to the conduction band edge.
(x) is located in the Si bandgap, relatively close to the valence band.
( ) is located out of the Si bandgap, relatively close to the valence band edge.

[explanation]
The acceptor state traps an electron, so it can not be positioned in the conduction band.
By trapping an electron, it generates a mobile hole. So the acceptor state is neither in the valence band. It has to be in the bandgap. 

By p-doping the holes (positive charge carriers) become the majority charge carriers, and therefore the energy of the acceptor state will be closer to the valence band than to the conduction band.
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following components is NOT part of a pure grid-connected PV system
     ( ) PV panels
     ( ) Inverter
     (x) Battery
     ( ) Distribution panel
     
[explanation]
Batteries are usually used either in standalone PV systems or in hybrid systems. If the system is grid connected, the extra energy produced will be pumped into the grid, and when the PV production is not enough to cover the demand, power is withdrawn from the grid. In such a case, we could say that the grid acts as a kind of storage, and therefore batteries are not needed anymore.
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following statements is not true regarding the solar inverter topologies?
     ( ) Module level (micro)inverters are better suited to get the maximum power out of each PV module than compared to central inverters, especially when there are partially shaded arrays.
     ( ) String inverters ensure a higher yield than central inverters when there are partially shaded arrays.
     (x) String inverters ensure a higher yield than module level (micro)inverters when there are partially shaded arrays.
     ( ) Module level (micro)inverters ensure a higher yield than string inverters when there are partially shaded arrays.
     
[explanation]
If the arrays are partially shaded, not all panels are under the same illumination. Under such a condition, maximum power can be extracted from the PV array if each panel is delivering maximum power pertaining to that illumination level. Module level inverters track the MPP for each panel, while string inverters track the MPP for each string, and the central inverters track the MPP for the whole array. Therefore, higher yields can be expected from module level inverter topology than string inverter topology; and higher yields can be expected from string inverter topology than central inverter topolgy.

[explanation]

Consider a p-n junction under equilibrium. Which of the following statements are TRUE?
You can check more than one answer!!

[x] The Fermi level is constant over position. 
[ ] The internal electric field causes a space charge region.
[ ] A net current is created through the junction. 
[x] The diffusion and drift currents compensate each other.  

[explanation]
1.- The Fermi energy represents the averaged electrochemical potential of the electrons. In an equilibirum state, the average electrochemical potential is the same through the entire junction. 
2.- When the p- and n-type regions are 'in contact', the diffusion of majority carriers leads to a region close to the metallurgical junction which is almost completely depleted of mobile charge carriers. This gives rise to a space charge created by the charge of the ionized donor and acceptor atoms that is not compensated by the mobile charges any more. This space charge results in the formation of an internal electric field.
3,4.- At equilibrium, the diffusion and drift currents compensate each other such that no net current can be observed. 
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Consider two solar cells: Solar cell "A" has a bandgap energy of 1 eV and solar cell "B" has a bandgap energy of 1.7 eV. From all kind of possible losses, assume only the optical losses. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
     ( ) Non-absorption losses are higher in solar cell A than in solar cell B. 
     (x) Heating losses are higher in solar cell A than in solar cell B.
     ( ) According to the Shockley-Queisser analysis, radiative recombination is more important in solar cell B than in solar cell A. 
     ( ) According to the Shockley-Queisser analysis, solar cell A can have an efficiency up to 50%. 
     
[explanation]
Non-absorption losses are dominant in high-bandgap materials. Since less photons are absorbed, less electron-hole pairs are generated and, as a consequence, radiative recombinations are lower. On the other hand, heating losses and radiative recombinations are dominant in low-bandgap materials.

Moreover, for bandgap energies between 1 and 1.5 eV, the Shockley-Queisser analysis sets a maximum efficiency around 33%. 
 
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Which of the effects listed below are considered to be main limiting factors for increasing the current density of the photoelectrodes?
	[x] Bandgap of the semiconductor forming the photoelectrode
	[ ] Reflection in the electrolyte between the light source and the photoelectrode
	[x] Separation of charges in the photoelectrode semiconductor material
    [x] Catalaytic effects in the photoelectrode surface
    [ ] Mass transport of the ion within the electrolyte 

     
[explanation]
Absorption of the semiconductor material limits the possibility of the photoelectrode to use the available light to create charge carriers. Since the absorption of light in a semiconductor material depends on the bandgap of such material, this will limit the amount of current that is produced.
Also, the separation of charge in the photoelectrode is a main concern. Often, the electric field formed is not enough to separate charges, and also the material has a relatively high density of defects, causing high recombination rates in the semiconductor.
Finally, the catalysis of the reaction is important. High overpotentials are needed to cover the activation energy of the reaction. However, if a catalyst is introduced, this activation energy is reduced and the reaction does not need such high overpotentials to occur.
In comparison, the reflection caused by the water and the mass transport of the ion whithin the electrolyte are minor effects.
[explanation]

metadata.discussion_target: HW 1.4 PV potential around the world
4.3 Design Rules of the c-Si Solar Cell

metadata.markdown:
In this section, we talked about combining a solar cell with a photoelectrode to form a photoelectrochemical device. Why do we add a solar cell in the system?
     ( ) Because the photoelectrode is not able to produce any voltage difference to drive the reaction
     ( ) Because the photoelectrode is not able to produce any current to drive the reaction
     (x) Because the voltage difference created in the photoelectrode is not able to produce enough voltage to drive the reaction
     ( ) Because the current created in the photoelectrode is not enough to drive the reaction

What is the approximate voltage that the solar cell needs to deliver for the photoelectrochemical device to work?
	( ) 0.6V
    ( ) 1.23V
    (x) 1.43V
    ( ) 0.8V
     
[explanation]
The voltage difference is the one that drives the reaction, the current is only a measure of at what rate the reaction is happening.

The photoelectrode itself produces some voltage difference, but it is not enough to drive the reaction. That is why the solar cell is needed.

The voltage needed can be calculated as

Redox potential + Overpotential = Photoelectrode potential + Solar cell potential

Therefore

Solar cell potential = 1.23V + 0.8V - 0.6V = 1.43V

[explanation]

What is NOT true about a semiconductor at room temperature and in the dark?

( ) The band gap of the semiconductor is within a range of 0.5 eV to 3eV.
( ) In a semiconductor electrons almost fully fill the valence band.
( ) In a semiconductor only a few electrons fill the conduction band.
(x) In a semiconductor the valence band is fully filled with electrons.
     
[explanation]
A semiconductor is characterized by a limited mobility of electrons. For electrons to move throughout the material, they need to be given the energy to excite them from the valence band into the conduction band. That energy can be given thermally or by photons (through the photovoltaic effect). Since the semiconductor is at room temperature, there is enough thermal energy to excite some of the electrons from the valence band into the conduction band. Therefore the valence band cannot be fully filled with electrons, even though the semiconductor is in the dark.
[explanation]

metadata.markdown:
Which of the following processes is used in order to fabricate poly-silicon?
(Note that more than one answer is possible)
     [ ] The Czochralski process
     [x] Fluid bed reactor process
     [ ] The float-zone process
     [x] The Siemens process
     
[explanation]
The Czochralski and the float-zone processes are used in order to obtain mono-crystalline silicon. 
[explanation]

What are the ‘free’ carriers in the different electronic bands of a semiconductor?
(x) Electrons in conduction band and holes in valence band
( ) Holes in conduction band and electrons in valence band
( ) Both electrons and holes in conduction band when an electric field is applied
( ) Both electrons and holes in valence band when an electric field is applied

[explanation]
The 'free' carriers can also be called charge carriers, and are the entities that move along each band. When conduction occurs, the electrons are excited in to the conduction band and become mobile, while a mobile hole is left behind in the valence band.
[explanation]
